properties.media:imagetext:
PACIFIC COMMERCE
Eleven
Advantages of South San Francisco
Airport Site No. 2
explained by the
South San Francisco Chamber of Commerce
SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO
SAN MATEO COUNTY
reianon to
San Francisco
Vivid Picturization of Proposed South San Francisco Airport Site
1. It is the nearest site to San Francisco located within the
area selected by the Aerial Affairs Committee of the San
Francisco Chamber of Commerce, being 7½ miles in an
air line from the San Francisco Post Office.
2. It is within the SAN FRANCISCO SWITCHING LIMITS, thus
affording aeroplane factories the same economic advan-
tages as if located within San Francisco.
3. It is valuable water front property, being located on the
SAN
BRUNO CANAL-
-a Federal
Government
defined
canal—which will ACCOMODATE HYDROPLANES, and at the
same time obtain for San Francisco water front property
which will enhance in value much more rapidly because
it is located on a defined government canal and because
it is also within the San Francisco switching limits.
4. It is served by Southern
Pacific, Belt Line Railroad and
Market Street Railroad.
5. It is served by the new Bay Shore Highway and the Hill-
side Boulevard and is indirectly served by the Penin-
sula Highway and the Skyline Boulevard.
6. It is located 1800 ft. from the Southern Pacific depot in
South San Francisco.
7. It is located on the new Bay Shore Highway 1500 ft. be-
yond the underpass at South San Francisco.
8. It would draw traffic from the 30 large factories located
here, because South san Francisco 1s within the san
Francisco switching limits.
CONCLUSION
It meets the requirements of a MUNICIPAL AIRPORT as set
forth to the Board of Superivsors by the various aviators and.
experts.
One of the primary policies necessary to serve, encourage
and develop aviation is to establish numerous airports that as
many cities as possible should establish a municipal airport.
Carrying out this policy the Bay cities, such as Oakland,
Alameda and Richmond, should each have an airport and the
San Francisco peninsula should have several properly located,
so that an aviator whose destination is the bay district can at
all times depend upon finding accomodations or suitable con-
ditions at some of these airports, and be in a position to select
the most favorable at which to land, with respect to the ulti-
mate destination of his passengers or cargo.
It meets the requirement as the practical location for San
Francisco's municipal airport as defined by the Department of
Commerce wherein it states that "when there is an option
between two or more, the distance from business district and
accessibility should be given first weight."
